habitat_description:
Myotis volans inhabits: douglas-fir forest, from xeric associations with ponderosa pine to mesic associations with western hemlock (Finley et al., 1983; Worthington, 1991; Ormsbee and McComb, 1998; Allen, 1999; Arnett, 2007; Arnett and Hayes, 2009); mixed conifer forest, sometimes with quaking aspen or gambel oak (Jones, 1961; Jones, 1965; Fenton et al., 1983; Pierson et al., 1996; Ports and Bradley, 1996; Pierson and Rainey, 1998; Allen, 1999; Baker and Lacki, 2006; Johnson et al., 2007; Lacki et al., 2010); subalpine forests (Jones, 1965); limber and bristlecone pine woodlands (Szewczak et al., 1998); aspen groves (Foster et al., 1997; Pettit and Wilkins, 2012); ponderosa pine forest and woodland (Jones, 1965; Foster et al., 1997; Morrell et al., 1999; Cryan et al., 2000; Baker and Lacki, 2006; Johnson et al., 2007; Lacki et al., 2010); pinyon-juniper woodland and savanna (Jones, 1965; Bell, 1980; Finley et al., 1983; Worthington, 1991; Chung-MacCoubrey, 1996; Ports and Bradley, 1996; Foster et al., 1997; Jackson and Herder 1997; Szewczak et al., 1998; Kuenzi et al., 1999; Siders, 2005); mixed forests of oak with pine, Douglas-fir, or juniper (Jones, 1965; Foster et al., 1997; Morrell et al., 1999; Seidman and Zabel, 2001); and riparian forests (Bell, 1980; Saunders and Barclay, 1992; Jackson and Herder 1997).

Generally said to be limited to forests and to high elevations in the continental interior (Dalquest, 1938; Jones, 1965; Warner and Czaplewski, 1984; Allen, 1999; Kuenzi et al., 1999), recent studies have shown the species to be present in shrublands of sagebrush, greasewood, rabbitbrush, and/or shadscale (Findley, 1954; Easterla, 1965; Foster et al., 1997; Jackson and Herder 1997; Szewczak et al., 1998; Siders, 2004; Siders, 2005) and occasionally in low elevation desert scrub (Bell, 1980; Expert reviews provided for the Southwest Gap Analysis). Stock (1970) recorded a single individual at low elevation (~1000 m) in Utah, near riparian vegetation within a creosote and sagebrush shrubland; however, he attributed this observation to migratory use. Easterla (1965) has documented the species as far as three miles from the nearest forest, though he did not indicate the number of individuals or whether it was a migrant or transient.

The long-legged bat roosts in: tree cavities or under the bark of both snags and live trees (Jones et al., 1973; Chung-MacCoubrey, 1996; Cryan, 1997; Ormsbee and McComb, 1998; Rabe et al., 1998; Cryan et al., 2001; Allen, 1999; Arnett, 2007; Johnson et al., 2007; Arnett and Hayes, 2009; Lacki et al., 2010); rock outcrops and cliffs (Cryan et al., 2001; Baker and Lacki, 2006); under bridges (Perlmeter, 1996; Pierson et al., 1996; Ormsbee and McComb, 1998); caves (Schowalter, 1980); and in buildings (Dalquest and Ramage, 1946; Findley, 1954; Genoways, 1967).

The species forages high above surface and above vegetation (Saunders and Barclay, 1992), typically near water (Jones et al., 1973; Finley et al., 1983; Morrell et al., 1999; Baker and Lacki, 2006), but it has also been observed foraging along cliffs and within riparian forest (Saunders and Barclay, 1992).

Few studies have explicitly examined or documented the role of water proximity in the species’ habits. Ormsbee and McComb (1998) noted that day roosts averaged from 230 to 352 m from the nearest streams; however, these distances were not significantly different from those of random plots.

Little is known of the species’ winter range or of its hibernacula characteristics; however it has been documented hibernating in caves  and mines (Perkins et al., 1990; Szewczak et al., 1998; Oliver, 2000).

The species’ elevation range is from near sea-level, along the coast, to 3770 m (Warner and Czaplewski, 1984; Fitzgerald et al., 1994). In the interior of the U.S., the species is generally documented between roughly 2000 and 3000 m in elevation (Hoffman et al., 1969; Finley et al., 1983; Warner and Czaplewski, 1984; Mollhagen and Bogan, 1997; Morrell et al., 1999; Rickart et al., 2008).
